title: It was typical Roman practice that successful candidates in municipal elections showed their gratitude by making a large payment (summa honoraria) to the community, often to pay for munera legitima (gladiatorial games and venationes) for their fellow citizens; indeed in some communities it was mandatory to do so. A similar procedure operated upon election to the high priesthood of the provincial council. R. Duncan-Jones, The Economy of the Roman Empire
